c0.orig: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image, nuclei appear as numerous small, round fluorescent dots packed throughout the tissue. Together they form a dense speckled texture that maps cell density and laminar patterns in three dimensions.
rewrites: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image, nuclei are labeled as numerous, high-contrast puncta, forming a dense, speckled texture that represents three-dimensional distributions of cell nuclei.

In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image, nuclei are labeled as numerous, high-contrast puncta, forming a dense, speckled texture that delineates cellular distribution and laminar organization in the three-dimensional tissue.
In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image, nuclei are labeled as numerous, high-contrast puncta. Their three-dimensional arrangement reveals cell density and laminar patterns.

In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image, nuclei are labeled as numerous, high-contrast puncta, forming a dense, three-dimensional texture that represents cell distribution and laminar organization.

In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image, nuclei are labeled with a fluorophore and appear as numerous, small, round fluorescent structures. Their high-contrast distribution creates a dense, speckled texture that represents cellular density and laminar organization in three dimensions.

c1.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy imaging of a cleared mouse brain reveals sparse, intensely bright neurons highlighted by viral tracing. The fluorescent signal outlines individual somata and extended processes, making the morphology of projection neurons clearly distinguishable from the surrounding background.
rewrites: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared mouse brain depicts sparsely distributed neurons labeled by viral tracing, with intense fluorescence. Individual neuronal somata and processes are discernible due to the high contrast, enabling the morphology of projection neurons to be distinguished from the background.

c2.orig: The autofluorescence channel in light-sheet microscopy produces a soft, diffuse glow across the cleared tissue. Rather than marking specific cells, this broad signal outlines gross anatomical features and boundaries, serving as a structural reference for the dataset.
rewrites: In light-sheet microscopy, autofluorescence generates a gentle, widespread illumination across the cleared specimen. This nonspecific signal delineates large-scale anatomical structures and demarcates tissue boundaries, providing a structural framework for the dataset.
Light-sheet autofluorescence imaging provides a uniform, low-contrast signal across the cleared tissue, highlighting gross anatomical structures and boundaries.
In light-sheet microscopy, the autofluorescence channel generates a uniform, low-intensity signal across the cleared tissue, delineating large-scale anatomical structures and tissue boundaries.
Light-sheet autofluorescence imaging reveals a uniform, low-intensity signal across the cleared tissue, highlighting gross anatomical structures and boundaries.

In light-sheet microscopy, the autofluorescence channel generates a uniform, low-intensity emission across the cleared tissue, highlighting overall tissue structure and providing a reference for anatomical landmarks within the dataset.

artery.orig: In this 3D light-sheet microscopy reconstruction of a cleared mouse brain, arteries emerge as broad, glowing tubes that branch into finer arterioles. The signal traces the hierarchical vascular tree, with thick trunks splitting into smaller fluorescent paths coursing through the parenchyma.
rewrites: In this 3D light-sheet microscopy reconstruction of a cleared mouse brain, arteries are depicted as wide, fluorescent structures that bifurcate into smaller arterioles. The signal delineates the hierarchical vascular tree, with prominent trunks dividing into multiple fluorescent branches within the parenchyma.

The vasculature is visualized as hierarchical structures, with thicker trunks dividing into multiple fluorescent branches within the parenchyma.

In this 3D light-sheet microscopy reconstruction of a cleared mouse brain, arteries are depicted as wide, fluorescent structures that bifurcate into smaller arterioles. The vascular tree is visualized through the hierarchical organization of these structures, with larger trunks dividing into multiple, thinner fluorescent vessels.

background.orig: Cleared mouse brain tissue imaged by light-sheet microscopy shows faint, diffuse autofluorescence. Instead of sharp puncta or filaments, the background glow outlines gross anatomy and cortical layering, providing soft contrast that situates the brighter labeled structures.
rewrites: Light-sheet microscopy reveals faint, diffuse autofluorescence in cleared mouse brain tissue, delineating large-scale anatomical features and cortical layering with subtle contrast.

Light-sheet microscopy reveals faint, diffuse autofluorescence in cleared mouse brain tissue, delineating gross anatomy and cortical layering with subtle contrast. Labeled structures exhibit higher fluorescence intensity.

background2.orig: Cleared mouse brain tissue imaged by light-sheet microscopy shows faint, diffuse autofluorescence. Instead of sharp puncta or filaments, the background glow outlines gross anatomy and cortical layering, providing soft contrast that situates the brighter labeled structures.

lectin.orig: Lectin staining of vasculature in a 3D LSFM dataset produces delicate, lace-like threads running throughout the brain. Microvessels and capillaries appear as intricate glowing filaments, weaving a dense vascular web across cortical and subcortical regions.
rewrites: Lectin immunolabeling in 3D light-sheet fluorescence microscopy data reveals vasculature as fine, interconnected filaments. Microvessels and capillaries are identified as labeled structures within this network.

Lectin immunolabeling reveals vasculature as fine, interconnected filaments in the 3D LSFM dataset. Microvessels and capillaries are identified as labeled structures. The vascular network is depicted as dense and extensive, spanning cortical and subcortical regions.

microtubule.orig: Microtubule labeling in light-sheet fluorescence microscopy reveals a filamentous scaffold within neurons. Fine fluorescent fibers extend along axons and dendrites, forming an intricate mesh of glowing cytoskeletal tracks that captures the internal framework of neural processes.
rewrites: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy reveals microtubules as filamentous structures within neurons, with fine fluorescent fibers extending along axons and dendrites. This intricate mesh of cytoskeletal tracks, visualized as glowing lines, represents the internal framework of neural processes.

neurofilament.orig: Axonal architecture is highlighted by neurofilament staining, which appears in LSFM images as thick, fibrous fluorescent strands interlaced with thinner fibers. Together they form bright, elongated tracts that map out long-range neuronal projections across the brain.
rewrites: Neurofilament immunolabeling reveals axonal structures as thick, fibrous fluorescent strands interspersed with thinner fibers in LSFM images. These structures delineate elongated tracts, mapping long-range neuronal projections within the brain.

neurotrace.orig: NeuroTrace labeling marks neuronal somata, producing bright, rounded signals scattered through gray matter. In three dimensions, the stain forms a dense constellation of glowing cell bodies, emphasizing laminar distribution and separating neuronal populations from surrounding tissue.
rewrites: NeuroTrace immunolabeling highlights neuronal somata as distinct, spherical structures with high fluorescence intensity in gray matter. In three dimensions, these structures form a dense aggregation, accentuating their laminar arrangement and distinguishing neuronal populations from neighboring tissue.

syto16.orig: Syto16 nuclear staining produces a cloud of tiny, brilliant points filling the tissue volume. Each nucleus glows as a distinct dot, and together they create a fine speckled texture that reveals overall cell density and cortical laminar patterns in 3D reconstructions.
rewrites: Syto16 nuclear labeling results in numerous, high-contrast puncta distributed throughout the tissue volume. Each nucleus is discernible as an individual point, and the collective appearance of these points delineates overall cellular density and cortical laminar architecture in three-dimensional reconstructions.

calretinin.orig: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared human cortical slice (BA44/45), calretinin-positive interneurons are visible. The staining produces bright punctate somata with delicate fluorescent processes, giving rise to a sparse, scattered pattern of glowing cells concentrated in superficial cortical layers.
rewrites: Calretinin immunolabeling highlights interneurons in a cleared human cortical slice (BA44/45) as punctate structures with bright somata and fine fluorescent processes, resulting in a sparse, scattered distribution primarily in superficial cortical layers.

gad67.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared human cortical slice labeled for GAD67, a marker of GABAergic neurons. The staining produces bright cytoplasmic fluorescence filling neuronal somata and proximal processes, creating a scattered constellation of glowing inhibitory neurons that outlines the distribution of the cortical GABAergic network.
rewrites: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared human cortical slice, labeled for GAD67. The image depicts GAD67-positive neuronal somata and proximal processes with bright cytoplasmic fluorescence. The scattered distribution of these structures represents the cortical GABAergic network.

neun.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a SWITCH/TDE-cleared human cortical section immunolabeled for NeuN. The marker generates intense nuclear and perinuclear fluorescence, revealing dense fields of glowing neuronal cell bodies across cortical laminae, with sharp contrast between gray and white matter.
rewrites: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a human cortical section cleared with SWITCH/TDE protocol and immunolabeled for NeuN. NeuN immunoreactivity produces intense nuclear and perinuclear fluorescence, highlighting distinct neuronal cell bodies as bright puncta against the contrasting gray and white matter backgrounds.

nuclei.orig: The nuclear stain in this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of cleared human brain tissue produces numerous small, round fluorescent signals. Each nucleus appears as a tiny glowing sphere, generating a fine-grained, speckled pattern of high density in cortical laminae and reduced density in underlying white matter.
rewrites: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of cleared human brain tissue, nuclear staining results in multiple small, round fluorescent foci. Each nucleus is visualized as a distinct, glowing sphere, yielding a speckled pattern of high fluorescence intensity in cortical laminae and lower intensity in underlying white matter.

somatostatin.orig: Somatostatin-positive interneurons are highlighted in this 3D light-sheet reconstruction of a cleared human cortex slice. The antibody staining yields bright, isolated fluorescent cell bodies in deeper cortical layers, often accompanied by faint dendritic extensions, creating a sparse but distinct distribution of inhibitory neurons within the tissue.
rewrites: In this 3D light-sheet reconstruction of a cleared human cortex slice, somatostatin-positive interneurons are identified by their bright, isolated fluorescence. These cells are primarily located in deeper cortical layers, with some dendritic extensions also visible as faint fluorescence. The distribution of these inhibitory neurons is sparse but distinct within the tissue.

ab_plaque.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared transgenic mouse brain containing amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques. The tissue was immunolabeled with antibodies against Aβ, producing bright fluorescence that reveals extracellular plaque deposits distributed throughout cortical and subcortical regions. The labeling highlights dense-core plaques and surrounding structures, enabling visualization of hallmark Alzheimer's disease pathology in three dimensions.
rewrites: Three-dimensional light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared transgenic mouse brain, where amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques are immunodetected using antibodies. The image reveals extracellular Aβ deposits distributed in cortical and subcortical areas, with dense-core plaques and surrounding structures distinctly labeled.

The image reveals numerous plaque deposits distributed in cortical and subcortical areas, with dense-core plaques and surrounding structures distinctly visible.

astrocytes.orig: In this mouse brain imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) immunolabeling reveals star-shaped astrocytic cell bodies and intricate filamentous processes. The signal appears as bright, branching fluorescent fibers that weave through the tissue, forming a complex three-dimensional network that stands out clearly from the surrounding background.
rewrites: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a mouse brain, GFAP immunolabeling highlights astrocytic somata and processes as bright, branching structures. The resulting fluorescent signal forms a complex three-dimensional network, distinguishable from the background.

cfos.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared WT adult mouse brain, immunolabeled with antibodies against the activity-dependent protein c-Fos. The staining produces bright fluorescence in c-Fos-positive neurons, revealing the distribution of recently activated cells across brain regions. This labeling enables whole-brain mapping of neuronal activity patterns by highlighting somata and dendritic processes of active neurons within the tissue.
rewrites: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared WT adult mouse brain section, labeled with antibodies against c-Fos. The immunolabeling results in bright fluorescence in neurons expressing c-Fos, delineating their somata and dendritic processes. This labeling facilitates whole-brain analysis of neuronal activity by visualizing the distribution of activated neurons within the tissue.

chondrogenic_cells.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared human embryo head (PCW5.6-PCW11.3), immunolabeled for Sox9. ctip2_neurons.orig: In a cleared mouse brain imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for CTIP2 (BCL11B) marks deep-layer cortical projection neurons, particularly in layer V. The stain produces bright, nuclear and perinuclear fluorescence within these neurons, forming dense clusters of glowing somata in the lower cortical layers and scattered signal in subcortical projection regions. The labeled cells stand out sharply from the surrounding tissue, revealing the laminar organization of CTIP2-positive neurons in three dimensions.

lyve1_lymphatic_vessel.orig: In the cleared mouse brain, immunolabeling for LYVE1 highlights slender, branching fluorescent vessels that trace the pathways of the meningeal and perivascular lymphatic network. Viewed with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, these delicate tubular structures appear as continuous glowing strands outlining the brain’s lymphatic architecture in three dimensions.
rewrites: LYVE1 immunolabeling reveals slender, branching structures in the cleared mouse brain, which represent the meningeal and perivascular lymphatic network. These tubular structures are visualized as continuous, glowing strands using light-sheet fluorescence microscopy.

nf_peripheral_nerve.orig: In the cleared mouse head, neurofilament (NF) immunolabeling reveals bright, thread-like fluorescent fibers representing peripheral nerves. The labeled axons appear as fine, elongated strands coursing through brain-adjacent tissues, forming a distinct filamentous network visible in three dimensions under light-sheet fluorescence microscopy.
rewrites: Neurofilament immunolabeling in the cleared mouse head highlights elongated, thread-like structures corresponding to peripheral nerves. These axons are visualized as fine, filamentous strands traversing brain-adjacent tissues in three dimensions using light-sheet fluorescence microscopy.

nucleus.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy imaging of centimeter-scale cleared human brain slices treated with the SHANEL deep-tissue histology protocol. Following permeabilization and delipidation, nuclei were labeled with propidium iodide (PI) or TO-PRO-3, producing stable fluorescent signals across large tissue volumes. This labeling enabled three-dimensional mapping of nuclear organization, revealing the density and morphology of cell populations across cortical and subcortical regions, and supporting long-term structural studies of intact human brain tissue.

p75_nerves.orig: In the cleared mouse head imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for the p75 neurotrophin receptor (p75 NTR) highlights peripheral and cranial nerves with strong, continuous fluorescence. The labeled fibers appear as smooth, tubular fluorescent strands tracing nerve pathways through the tissue, often running in parallel bundles. This staining delineates the glowing trajectories of peripheral nerves and their branching patterns in three dimensions.

These smooth, thread-like strands run through brain-adjacent tissues and along the skull base, forming a clear three-dimensional network of nerve projections visible under light-sheet fluorescence microscopy.
rewrites: In the cleared mouse head, PGP9.5 immunolabeling reveals slender, fluorescent fibers representing cranial and peripheral nerves. sma_artery.orig: In the cleared mouse head imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for smooth muscle actin (SMA) highlights arterial walls as bright, continuous tubular structures. The signal forms thick, glowing vessels that branch into smaller arterioles, showing the smooth, layered morphology characteristic of muscular arteries. These fluorescent tubes trace the three-dimensional architecture of the arterial network, standing out clearly against the surrounding tissue.
rewrites: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy reveals SMA immunolabeling as intense, continuous structures delineating arterial walls in the cleared mouse head. The labeled structures exhibit thick, luminescent features, branching into smaller arterioles, and maintaining the layered morphology typical of muscular arteries. These fluorescent structures accurately depict the three-dimensional organization of the arterial network.

th_neurons.orig: Immunolabeling for tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) in light-sheet fluorescence microscopy reveals bright, fluorescent neuronal somata and slender processes characteristic of dopaminergic and noradrenergic cells. The labeled neurons form distinct clusters of glowing cell bodies with projecting fibers visible in three dimensions, delineating catecholaminergic populations across midbrain and brainstem regions.
rewrites: TH immunolabeling in light-sheet fluorescence microscopy highlights dopaminergic and noradrenergic neurons as distinct clusters of brightly labeled somata and elongated processes. The three-dimensional image reveals projecting fibers, defining catecholaminergic populations in midbrain and brainstem regions.

In light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, TH immunolabeling highlights somata and processes of dopaminergic and noradrenergic neurons as bright, fluorescent structures. These neurons are distinguishable as clusters of labeled cell bodies with projecting fibers, illustrating the distribution of catecholaminergic populations in midbrain and brainstem regions.

th_sympathetic_nerve.orig: In the cleared mouse head imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) reveals bright, thin fluorescent fibers corresponding to sympathetic nerves. These labeled axons form delicate, branching networks that follow blood vessels and peripheral pathways. The staining produces fine, glowing filaments that trace the distribution of catecholaminergic innervation in three dimensions.
rewrites: In the cleared mouse head imaged via light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, TH immunolabeling highlights thin, fluorescent fibers representing sympathetic axons. vessel_eb.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared adult mouse brain, labeled with Evans Blue (EB). EB dye was injected intraperitoneally 12 hours before fixation, allowing it to circulate with serum albumin and strongly label large blood vessels such as the middle cerebral artery and the circle of Willis. The fluorescence signal in the 640 nm range highlights the architecture of major vessels with high contrast, enabling whole-brain vascular mapping.

vessel_wga.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared adult mouse brain, perfused during fixation with wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) conjugated to Alexa 594. WGA binds to the endothelial glycocalyx, producing bright signal in the 561 nm channel and strongly labeling microvessels and capillaries with high signal-to-noise ratio. This staining provides detailed visualization of fine-scale vasculature throughout the brain.

01_aa1_po_c_r45.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy patch from a cleared adult wildtype (WT) mouse brain. Tissue was immunostained for tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), a marker of dopaminergic neurons. Fluorescence was captured in the 639 nm channel. TH signal is localized to the cytoplasm of neuronal soma, producing intense, homogeneous labeling of dopaminergic cells. This image highlights detailed cellular morphology within the brain region.

02_az10_sr3b_6_a.orig: 3D light-sheet microscopy image patch acquired from a cleared wildtype adult mouse brain. Immunolabeling for CTIP2, a nuclear transcription factor involved in cortical neuron differentiation, was performed and visualized using the 561 nm fluorescence channel. CTIP2 staining reveals nuclear-localized puncta within deep-layer projection neurons, with clearly defined nuclear boundaries and dense labeling patterns.

03_aj12_lg1e_n_a.orig: Volumetric fluorescence image from an adult WT mouse brain section stained for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), an intermediate filament protein expressed in astrocytes. The tissue was imaged using light-sheet microscopy in the 639 nm channel. GFAP signal is distributed throughout the astrocytic cytoplasm and processes, producing a filamentous pattern that outlines astrocyte morphology and highlights the fine arborization of glial networks.

04_ae2_wf2a_a.orig: High-resolution light-sheet image patch from a cleared WT mouse brain, immunolabeled for the neurotrophin receptor p75NTR. Fluorescence signal was captured in the 639 nm channel. p75NTR is expressed in both the cytoplasm and plasma membrane of certain neurons and glial cells. The staining reveals membrane-associated fluorescence outlining cell boundaries and diffuse cytoplasmic signal, consistent with p75NTR localization in neurogenic regions.

05_ch1_pcw1a_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence image patch of an adult WT mouse brain showing immunolabeling for dopamine beta-hydroxylase (DBH), an enzyme involved in norepinephrine synthesis. Signal was acquired in the 639 nm channel. DBH is localized to the cytoplasm and synaptic vesicles of noradrenergic neurons. This image highlights punctate and cytoplasmic fluorescence, reflecting DBH's role in vesicular catecholamine transport and storage.

06_az10_sr3b_6_a.orig: Fluorescent nuclear staining in a cleared adult WT mouse brain, acquired using light-sheet microscopy. The DNA-binding dye SYTO 24 was used to label cell nuclei and was imaged in the 488 nm channel. The resulting pattern shows uniform, high-contrast labeling of nuclei throughout the tissue volume, facilitating identification of cell density and spatial organization across cortical and subcortical regions.

07_az10_sr3b_6_a.orig: Sparse neuronal labeling in a WT adult mouse brain, visualized via expression of cytoplasmic green fluorescent protein (GFP) from a pAAV viral vector. Acquired using light-sheet microscopy in the 639 nm channel, this patch contains isolated, fully labeled neuron soma and processes. The cytoplasmic GFP signal allows clear visualization of neuronal morphology and trajectory within descending motor pathways.

08_af3_br4_a1_a.orig: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared WT adult mouse brain, neurons expressing the G protein-coupled receptor 85 (GPR85) were labeled using systemic delivery of an AAV.PHP.eB-tdTomato viral vector. The labeling produces bright red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel, outlining GPR85-positive neuronal somata and processes against the background tissue.

09_bh1_tm2b_f_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch from the right central amygdala (CeA) of a cleared WT adult mouse brain. Neurons were sparsely labeled via iontophoretic delivery of an AAV2.1-tdTomato viral vector, producing bright red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel. The labeling highlights distinct neuronal somata and fine processes against a predominantly unlabeled background, enabling clear visualization of individual cell morphology.

10_af3_br6c_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch from a cleared WT adult mouse brain, highlighting neurons that express the serotonin receptor 5-HT2A. An AAV.PHP.eB-tdTomato viral vector was used for labeling, producing vivid red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel. The signal delineates 5-HT2A-positive neuronal somata and projections with clear contrast against surrounding tissue structures.

11_aa1_po40_1_a.orig: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared WT adult mouse brain, cells expressing the serotonin transporter (Sert) protein from embryonic development onward are visualized. A Cre::tdTomato genetic labeling strategy was used to drive red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel, highlighting Sert-positive neuronal cell bodies and processes with clear contrast against the surrounding tissue.

12_aa1_po40_3_a.orig: This light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch shows cells in a cleared WT adult mouse brain that express the prodynorphin (Pdyn) protein from embryonic development onward. Genetic labeling with Cre::tdTomato produces vivid red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel, revealing Pdyn-positive neuronal somata and projections with fine structural detail against the surrounding tissue background.

13_aa1_po40_4_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared WT adult mouse brain, showing neurons that have expressed vesicular glutamate transporter 3 (Vglut3) since embryonic development. Using a Cre::tdTomato genetic labeling approach, these Vglut3-positive cells exhibit bright red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel, making their somata and fine processes clearly visible within the surrounding tissue.

14_af3_br6b_d5_a.orig: This light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch shows neurons in a cleared WT adult mouse brain that express the serotonin receptor 5-HT2A. Labeling was achieved using a Cre-ERT2::tdTomato genetic strategy, resulting in bright red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel. The signal highlights 5-HT2A-positive neuronal somata and processes with fine structural detail visible against the background tissue.

15_al2_xd1b_a_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch from a cleared WT adult mouse brain, showing sparsely labeled retinal ganglion cell projections from the left eye. Using a Kcng::AAV-WGA-mCherry viral tracer, bright red fluorescence in the far-red channel reveals fine axonal fibers coursing through brain tissue toward central visual targets, including the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and superior colliculus, standing out clearly against surrounding structures.

18_ac17_cr7c_w23_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch from a mouse brain collected 8 days after footpad injection of West Nile Virus. The tissue was immunolabeled for the viral nonstructural protein NS1, producing bright signal in the 639 nm channel. The staining highlights infected cells and surrounding structures, enabling visualization of viral protein distribution within the brain.

19_aj12_lg1e_j_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain acquired in the 445 nm autofluorescence channel. The signal appears as a diffuse, low-intensity glow outlining general tissue architecture and anatomical features. Autofluorescence provides broad structural contrast but does not highlight specific cell types, serving instead as a contextual reference within the 3D dataset.

20_aj12_lg1e_j_a.orig: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, β-amyloid immunolabeling is visible as intensely fluorescent puncta distributed throughout the tissue. The deposits form irregular or rounded clusters of bright signal, marking extracellular plaque aggregates. These glowing spots are sharply contrasted against the surrounding parenchyma, allowing the three-dimensional pattern of amyloid plaques to be observed across cortical and hippocampal regions.

21_aj12_lg1e_j_a.orig: In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, phosphorylated paired helical filament tau (PHF-tau) is revealed by immunolabeling. The signal appears as irregular, brightly fluorescent accumulations within neuronal cell bodies and their processes. These deposits form clusters and streak-like patterns of light against the surrounding tissue, making the three-dimensional spread of tau pathology across vulnerable brain regions clearly visible.
rewrites: In this cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain imaged using light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, PHF-tau is detected by immunolabeling, resulting in irregular, bright fluorescent foci within neuronal somata and processes. These aggregates form clusters and elongated structures, revealing the three-dimensional distribution of PHF-tau in susceptible brain areas.

In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, PHF-tau is identified by immunolabeling as irregularly distributed, brightly fluorescent aggregates within neuronal somata and processes. These aggregates form clusters and streak-like structures, providing a three-dimensional representation of the PHF-tau distribution in the brain.

In this cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain imaged using light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, PHF-tau is identified by immunolabeling as irregular, brightly fluorescent aggregates within neuronal somata and processes. These aggregates form clusters and streak-like patterns, revealing the three-dimensional distribution of PHF-tau in the brain.

In this cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain imaged using light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, PHF-tau is detected by immunolabeling as irregular, bright fluorescent aggregates within neuronal somata and processes. These aggregates form clusters and elongated structures, revealing the three-dimensional distribution of PHF-tau in susceptible brain areas.

In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image, PHF-tau immunolabeling highlights irregular accumulations within neuronal somata and processes, appearing as bright fluorescent foci. These deposits form clusters and streak-like patterns, revealing the three-dimensional distribution of PHF-tau in the cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain.

In this light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, PHF-tau is detected by immunolabeling as irregular, brightly fluorescent aggregates within neuronal somata and processes. These aggregates form clusters and streak-like patterns, revealing the three-dimensional distribution of PHF-tau in the brain.

22_aj12_lg1e_j_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain immunolabeled for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The staining highlights astrocytic cell bodies and their fine processes as bright, filamentous fluorescent structures extending through the tissue. These glowing fibers form a dense, branching network that outlines astrocytic morphology in three dimensions, standing out distinctly against the darker background.
rewrites: Three-dimensional light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, immunolabeled for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The staining reveals astrocytic somata and processes as bright, filamentous structures, extending throughout the tissue. GFAP-labeled fibers form a complex, three-dimensional network, contrasting against the darker background.

Three-dimensional light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, immunolabeled for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The image depicts GFAP-labeled astrocytes as bright, filamentous structures, with somata and processes distinguishable. The fibers form a complex, three-dimensional network, contrasting against the darker background.

Three-dimensional light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, labeled for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The immunolabeling reveals astrocytic somata and processes as bright, filamentous structures, delineating a complex, three-dimensional network within the tissue.

Three-dimensional light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image of a cleared Alzheimer's disease model mouse brain, labeled for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The immunolabeling reveals astrocytic somata and processes as bright, filamentous structures, forming a dense, three-dimensional network of GFAP-positive fibers.

23_bh1_tm6a_a_a.orig: This light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch shows neurons in a cleared WT adult mouse brain that express dopamine β-hydroxylase (DBH) beginning in embryonic development. A Flp::tdTomato genetic labeling strategy was used, producing strong red fluorescence in the 639 nm channel. The labeling reveals DBH-positive neuronal somata and processes with clear contrast against the surrounding brain tissue.

24_bh1_tm6b_f_a.orig: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch from a cleared WT adult mouse brain, showing sparsely labeled neurons in the A1, A2, and A5 brainstem catecholaminergic groups, which are involved in autonomic and arousal regulation. Labeling was achieved with an AAV2.1-tdTomato viral vector, producing bright red fluorescence in the 561 nm channel. The signal highlights distinct neuronal somata and processes with clear contrast against the surrounding brain tissue.
